Eiffel Tower, a wrought - iron structure located in Paris is a technological masterpiece in building histories.
It was designed and built during 1887 by Gustave Eiffel and then was named in his honor too.

Having a height of 1,083 feet, a  weight of 10,000 tons and revited by 2.5 million rivets, this wondrous scape became the entrance gateway to the International exposition in 1889.
It was erected in two years, with a small labor force and at a low cost.  Designed as a well lit, airy, strong structure, which pioneered a revolution in civil engineering.

It remarkably stands on four lattice girder piers. The glass cage machines were designed by the US Otis Elevator Company, which later became the main feature of the building.

Though, Modifications were made for further international expositions of 1900, 1925, and 1937 but Additions to the tower were made for television transmissions only wherein 66 feet were added to it's height.

The tower features a museum (which we were unable to see), restaurants, and a much talked about Eiffel‚Äôs Reception Room providing space for business conferences, cultural events, and social gatherings.
An observation deck is located just under the antenna, at 906 feet.

The Eiffel Tower did not disappoint. Grab a beret and a baguette and look closer than the postcards. From far away, the tower seems light and decorative, but up close it feels strong and precise. The iron ‚Äúlace‚Äù is not decoration. It is the structure itself. Every curve and crisscross helps the tower stand tall against gravity and wind.

Gustave Eiffel designed the tower with wind in mind. As the tower rises, it becomes narrower because strong winds hit higher levels with more force. The curved shape lets wind pass around it instead of pushing straight against it. This design choice is why the tower has survived storms for more than a hundred years.

One of the most interesting features is that nothing is hidden. The iron beams, joints, and rivets are all visible. Over 18,000 iron pieces are held together by millions of rivets, allowing the tower to expand and contract as temperatures change. Even the elevators follow the curve of the legs instead of moving straight up. The Eiffel Tower proves that smart engineering can be beautiful without trying to be fancy.
